Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery open vessel, possibly a column-krater; interior glazed; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of fallen bull (head of bull fallen on its face, with right front hoof beside its face, to left; above its head, part of its assailant, possibly Herakles or lion); below, black (fired brown) band above glazed black zone.
Curator's comments: Compare Munich 1736, a column krater, side B: lions attacking bull in ABV, 265, no. 2: Painter of Munich 1736 (not far from Group of the Lysippides Painter); Vierneisel, K. and Kaeser, B., Kunst der Schale. Kultur des Trinkens. Munich 1990, 190, fig. 30.7 (= 10.8), dated c. 560 BC.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B600.5)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0162) (Phase 1)
